Selling Yourself

By Conor Organ. 27/4/2016

Creating your portfolio is an important part of becoming a designer. It will get you your first job and will grow with you as you develop of as a designer and as a person. It is important to show all your good attributes while still developing a personal style.

This is much easier said then done and requires a lot of work for you to be happy with it. Good thing in our CDC class we developed a handbook to help you create your portfolio! This 150 page document works your way from starting to create your portfolio to how to save it in InDesign to examples of good and bad portfolios.

Laying out your portfolio is an important part of this. You want a layout that catches the viewers eye while still easy to follow. You need to make sure your personal style is shown from the off.

Making a hands on portfolio will also help a viewer to remember which portfolio is yours and will help with getting a job. After researching creative portfolio designs we found examples of portfolios that use maps, pop out projects, cards and even as a cd booklet.

We found a number of resources that can be used to help you create your striking portfolio! The most important thing to use is InDesign. This is a programme developed by Adobe, the main purpose of this to create books and other printed projects. For developing a colour scheme we found colour.adobe.com and coolors.com. These can be used in conjunction with each other to make a stunning colour scheme for your portfolio.

All these resources can help you create the perfect print portfolio which will both catch the eye of viewers and get you a job!
